Situation1: They actively help a mentee navigate a challenging project with regular check-ins and feedback.
Situation2: Assisting at a traffic accident scene to ensure safety and order
Story: I was in the middle of a video call with Jamie, my mentee, guiding her through the final stages of her research project. She was anxious, and I could see how much she relied on my feedback to keep her on track. My phone buzzed—dispatch was calling. There’d been a traffic accident just a few blocks away, and I was the closest officer on duty. I glanced at Jamie, her eyes searching mine for reassurance, and then at the flashing notification on my phone. As a mentor, I was expected to be present, to provide steady guidance and support. As a police officer, I was sworn to protect the community, to respond quickly when people needed help. My mind raced, torn between the responsibility to my mentee and the urgent call to duty. I felt the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention, each too important to ignore. My heart pounded as I realized I had to choose, knowing that whichever path I took, I would be letting someone down.
